Title: Insular interconnections with the amygdala in the rhesus monkey

@BrainMaps_UnspecificAdoption.Citation: "The terminology used for the subdivisions of the insular cortex in the present report are based on the studies of Roberts & Akert (1963) and Jones & Burton (1976). In brief, the insula has been parcellated into agranular and dysgranular subfields anteriorly and a granular subfield more caudally. The nomenclature of the amygdaloid nuclei of the rhesus monkey is derived from the work of Lauer (1945) as well as Herzog & Van Hoesen (1976). Tissue stained for AChE aided in the delineation of the various amygdaloid subnuclei (Fig. 1)." (p. 1232)
@BrainMaps_UnspecificAdoption.Comments:
As we can see from the the citation above, it is not unambiguous  from which parcellation scheme the insular areas are adopted.
Furthermore , there are no abbreviations given for the parcellated insular areas. Because only the full names ("agranular", "dysgranular", and "granular" insular cortex) are given, we choose the nomenclature of Jones and Burton (1976), because their terms for these insular areas are a little bit more shorter and their paper is more recent.

In brief, the insula has been parcellated into agranular and dysgranular subfields anteriorly and a granular subfield more caudally. The nomenclature of the amygdaloid nuclei of the rhesus monkey is derived from the work of Lauer (1945) as well as Herzog & Van Hoesen (1976). Tissue stained for AChE aided in the delineation of the various amygdaloid subnuclei (Fig. 1)." (p. 1232)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: In this paper neither abbreviations nor borders are given for the insular areas.

@Injections.Citation:
"In case1, isotope was injected in the anterior insula (agranular and dysgranular) resulting in widespread labeled grains in the 
amygdala with minimal spread of isotope to the claustrum." (p. 1233)
@Injections.Comments: The injection site is shown in very unprecise way, because they only show an overview of the lateral surface without areal names and borders.  In case 4 the contralateral hemisphere of case 1 was used (p. 1232).

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "These two cases [case 1 and 2] demonstrate that the anterior insula has widespread connections with amygdala, whereas the posterior insula has a more limited field of projection." (p. 1233)

@LabelledSites_Data.Comments: The abbreviation for the "anterior amygdaloid area" is "aa", but the figures only show "a", which seems to stand also for the "anterior amygdaloid area", because it has approximately the same location.

@Injections.Citation: "In contrast to the above case, a more posterior isotope injection in the insula resulted in a limited projection pattern. In case 2, labeled amino acids were injected into the more posterior portion of insular cortex (dysgranular and granular) (Fig. 3). In this case, the injection occupied mostly the caudal one-third of the posterior insula, however, there was minimal spread of the isotope to the adjacent claustrum." (p. 1233)
@Injections.Comments: The injection site is shown in very unprecise way, because they only show an overview of the lateral surface without areal names and borders.  In case 5 the contralateral hemisphere of case 2 was used (p. 1232).

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "These two cases [case 1 and 2] demonstrate that the anterior insula has widespread connections with amygdala, whereas the posterior insula has a more limited field of projection." (p. 1233)

@LabelledSites_Data.Comments: The abbreviation for the "anterior amygdaloid area" is "aa", but the figures only show "a", which seems to stand also for the "anterior amygdaloid area", because it has approximately the same location.

@Injections.Citation:
"In order to determine the site of termination of the amygdaloid-insula projections, tritiated labeled amino acids were injected within the amygdala. In case 6, isotope was injected in the more medial portions of the amygdala which included the medial basal , the accessory basal and the cortical amygdaloid nuclei as well as some spread to the entorhinal cortex (Fig. 7)." (p. 1233)
"The injection site involves the accessory basal, corticomedial, medial basal, as well as the medial aspect of the lateral basal nuclei." (p. 1233, description of figure 7)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "The resulting labeled silver grains were observed predominantly in layers 2 and 5 and to a lesser extent in layer 3 of the agranular , dysgranular as well as the granular insular subfields (Figs. 8 and 9). The sites of termination are similar to those that contained labeled perikarya following an HRP injection into the amygdala." (p. 1233)

@Injections.Citation:
In case 7, isotope was injected in a more posterior portion of the amygdala (Figs. 10 and 11). The injection involved the caudal aspect of the lateral and lateral basal nuclei as well as a transition area between the amygdala and the hippocampus. The pattern of projections was distinctly different from the above case with a more medial amygdala isotope injection. Silver grains were only seen in the ventral portion of the anterior insula for a very limited distance. (Fig. 11). Thus, it appears that the major connections from the amygdala to the insula originate in the more anterior and medial portions of the amygdala ." (p. 1233)
"Photomicrograph of a coronal section through the caudal amygdala (case 7) showing isotope injection located in th eventral medial ortion of the lateral amygdaloid nucleus." (p. 1243, description of figure 10)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: In case 7, isotope was injected in a more posterior portion of the amygdala (Figs. 10 and 11). The injection involved the caudal aspect of the lateral and lateral basal nuclei as well as a transition area between the amygdala and the hippocampus. The pattern of projections was distinctly different from the above case with a more medial amygdala isotope injection. Silver grains were only seen in the ventral portion of the anterior insula for a very limited distance. (Fig. 11). Thus, it appears that the major connections from the amygdala to the insula originate in the more anterior and medial portions of the amygdala ." (p. 1233)
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: As you can see on page 1233, the "anterior insula" contains the "agranular and dysgranular" insular cortex, whereas the "posterior insula" contains the "dysgranular and granular" insular cortex.

@Injections.Citation: "Additional experiments were undertaken to demonstrate a reciprocal relationship between the amygdala and insula. In case 4, HRP was injected into the anterior insular cortex (agranular and dysgranular) (Fig. 5). The injection site probably included a limited portion of the underlying claustrum. While the extreme capsule also contained reaction-product, its fibers were not injured by the needle penetration. The HRP-positive cells in this case were observed in a location similar to the distribution of silver grains in case 1 in which the anterior insula had been injected with labeled amino acids." (p. 1233)
@Injections.Comments: The injection site is shown in very unprecise way, because they only show an overview of the lateral surface without areal names and borders. In case 4 the contralateral hemisphere of case 1 was used (p. 1232).

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "…These two cases [case 4 and 5] show that the anterior and medial amygdaloid nuclei have extensive projections to the anterior insula, whereas the lateral and to a lesser extent the lateral basal nuclei project mainly to the more posterior portions of the insular cortex." (p. 1233)

@LabelledSites_Data.Comments: The abbreviation for the "anterior amygdaloid area" is "aa", but the figures only show "a", which seems to stand also for the "anterior amygdaloid area", because it has approximately the same location.

@Injections.Citation: "In contrast to case 4, a more posterior HRP injection (Fig. 6) in the granular insula (case 5) resulted in a more discrete pattern. As in case 4, the injection site probably included a limited portion of the claustrum. Although reaction product was also observed in the extreme capsule, its axons were not damaged by needle penetration." (p. 1233)
@Injections.Comments: The injection site is shown in very unprecise way, because they only show an overview of the lateral surface without areal names and borders. In case 5 the contralateral hemisphere of case 2 was used (p. 1232).

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "…These two cases [case 4 and 5] show that the anterior and medial amygdaloid nuclei have extensive projections to the anterior insula, whereas the lateral and to a lesser extent the lateral basal nuclei project mainly to the more posterior portions of the insular cortex." (p. 1233)

publication.title: Insular interconnections with the amygdala in the rhesus monkey
